awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Investigation of Undergraduate Learning Contexts Considering Ethical, Racial, and Disciplinary Identities of Students in Engineering and Computer Science.
awd_abstract_narration:
The Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program is a National Science Foundation-wide activity that offers awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education, and the integration of education and research within the context of the mission of their organizations. This project has the goal to investigate how undergraduate learning contexts may constrain or facilitate productive interactions between ethical, racial, and disciplinary identities of students of color in engineering and computer science. The project integrates research and education by infusing the research in undergraduate and graduate education courses and by involving undergraduate and graduate students in the work. This award is supported by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program with co-funding by the Science, Technology and Society program. ECR emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. 

By combining longitudinal ethnographic and design-based approaches, this study contributes to the understanding of how undergraduate students of color experience the culture of engineering and computer science departments, while also exploring new educational possibilities that take seriously the ethical and sociocultural potential of these disciplines. The design component of the study, by synthesizing science and technology studies perspectives along with the benefits of undergraduate research experiences, creates novel opportunities for students to explore the ethical dimensions and social justice potential of new technologies. Empirical findings from the design experiment will help identify design and pedagogical principles that jointly cultivate multiple student identities within STEM learning environments. Finally, this project contributes to the scholarly and national conversation on issues of equity in STEM education in conceptually and methodologically unique ways. Few studies have considered the role of ethical identity in the experiences of students of color in engineering and computer science or examined their experiences over a sustained period and across multiple contexts. Findings from this study will contribute to fundamental learning sciences research on identity development in STEM, as well as to the knowledge base about how to design equitable STEM learning environments.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CAREER grant has been instrumental in advancing the design and research of learning environments focused on the intersections of technology, ethics, and power. It facilitated the establishment of the TREE Lab (Technology Race Ethics and Education Lab) within Northwestern University’s School of Education and Social Policy (SESP). The TREE Lab serves as an interdisciplinary hub where faculty, graduate and undergraduate students, local teachers, and community members collaborate on projects exploring the societal and ethical implications of technology. A cornerstone initiative of the TREE Lab is the Young People’s Race Power and Technology Project (YPRPT), launched in Summer 2019. Co-designed with teachers and community partners, YPRPT is an afterschool program for high school students and undergraduate mentors who investigate the local impacts of advanced technologies, including AI, with a specific focus on racially minoritized populations in Chicago. Through partnerships with local artists, YPRPT participants produce creative artifacts that explore the ethical and sociopolitical dimensions of focal technologies (Recent student-produced documentaries, zines, and other creative artifacts are available on our lab’s website). 

In addition to program and curriculum development, this project has significantly contributed to academic research by addressing the following key questions: How can we best support learning at the intersections of technology, ethics, and power? What knowledge, skills, and identities are essential for critically and creatively engaging with technology in our communities? And what are the implications for educational institutions and community organizations? Our findings underscore that effective learning about the ethics and politics of technology is enhanced by:

1) Recognizing and leveraging youth’s diverse experiences with technology in their schools and neighborhoods,

2) Partnering with community organizations with expertise in how advanced technologies impact local issues, (e.g., facial recognition technology and policing), 

3) Engaging youth in creative and artistic projects that invite them to explore and express their perspectives on technology through narrative, art, and storytelling, 

4) Developing curriculum that integrates technical understanding with rigorous examinations of ethical, social, and political topics.

Our lab has disseminated research findings in prestigious venues including the American Educational Research Association, International Conference of the Learning Sciences, and American Society for Engineering Education. We have published our findings in the Journal of Research in Science Teaching (JRST), Mind Culture and Activity (MCA), as well as the Proceedings of the International Conference of the Learning Sciences. A significant outcome of this project has been the enduring relationships with in-school and out-of-school educational providers in Evanston and Chicago whom we will continue collaborations with. In Summer 2024, we forged a new partnership with the Digital Youth Network and the Kapor Foundation to expand YPRPT across Chicagoland schools and communities. This collaboration aims to establish new programs and pathways for students interested in technology ethics, policy, racial equity, and education. Our ongoing research will continue to inform the work of educators, researchers, and policymakers dedicated to broadening access to tech ecosystems in ways that promote equity and opportunity for all.
